item.title: A Short Trip to Devil's Den
Mountain Village, Colorado
Sunset on Oahu
Arches National Park
Seeing Zion National Park
Our Trip to the Grand Canyon
Red Rock State Park
The Importance of Good Shoes
item.description: Never forget your good business shoes on a business trip. #roadwarrior #protip

item.title: My Worst Vacation Injuries
item.description: We’ve visited a few spots with some potential for accidents, but so far my worst vacation injuries have been banging my head on the roof of the car unloading luggage (last year; my neck was sore for days), and scraping up my arm pretty bad after tripping over luggage in the dark (last night). It seems I have a problem with luggage.

item.title: Road Trip Travel Log 09.01
item.description: Arrived in beautiful Telluride, Colorado, and yes, this is my first update since day #2 of vacation. So much for my Travel Log. Between lack of cell signal and surrendering my phone to the kid, and straight up being too busy and/or exhausted, I haven‚Äôt had much opportunity for posting. We‚Äôve been busy! Back to the Grand Canyon this year, and this time we got to spend a night in the park, with a chance to do some dawn/dusk shots of the canyon itself.

item.title: Road Trip Travel Log 02.02
item.description: Finally made it to Red Rock State Park, and made a couple of new discoveries along the way. Our route took us through what turned out be the incredibly beautiful Coconino National Forest, a place we have vowed to return. If Tolkien‚Äôs Elves were a real thing, they might just choose to live in a place like that. Verdant green forests around the bases of giant granite mountains, interspersed all along the way with little villages and expensive looking cabin retreats, with lights hanging from the trees across bridges that span crystal clear mountain streams.

item.title: Road Trip Travel Log 02.01
item.description: On the road from Albuquerque to Flagstaff, near which we turn south to Red Rock State Park in Arizona. The kids are keen to get in a hike today, the first ‚Äúreal‚Äù day of our vacation, as far as I‚Äôm concerned. It‚Äôs been fun watching the younger two get excited over taking pictures from the car with the little Instax Mini. That was Kassi‚Äôs great idea. We bought Anthony around 150 exposures and his eyes got wide when I told him I wanted him to use every single one by the end of the trip.

item.title: Road Trip Travel Log 01.02
item.description: Picture of me in the Llano Estacado, Texas‚Äôs ‚Äúwine country‚Äù. On the road for quite a while and still not out of the state. Holding up well. Fear the little one may be coming down with a cold. Hope he‚Äôs better after some rest. Changed restaurant plans and will revisit our old favorite in Albuquerque for the third year in a row. The food there has always been great, though the service is consistently slow.

item.title: Road Trip Travel Log 01.01
item.description: We‚Äôre well in to the big family road trip of 2019, and the obligatory Texas pit stop at Bucc-ees has been checked off the list. Would have sent you guys a pic from the storied Bucc-ees bathrooms, but I was too excited about these new hot n‚Äô spicy Beaver Nuggets! You can hear all about my first experience with those glorified Corn Pops in this review I did last year with my good buddy Brian.

item.title: See You in Arizona
item.description: It’s summer vacation time again, and I’m as excited as if I were returning to Hogwarts after a summer at the Dursley’s ‚Äî¬†a completely made up expression that I thought of just now purely as an excuse to post the picture below, of which I happen to be fond. Back when I had hair I might have been able to pass off a kind of Harry Potter-esque look. Now it’s more like Filch.

item.title: Pasadena Tour
Taking Kassi to the Channel Islands
Visiting Sequoia National Park
Flight to LA With Kassi
The Dad Wagon is in Vacation Mode
item.description: Must be time for a road trip, because I find myself wondering what the wagon would look like with wood paneling. üöô‚õ∞üèú

item.title: Farewell Pasadena
Bits and Bobs
item.description: I made a promise to myself that I would never waste time on this blog apologizing for sporadic posting. So instead of doing that, I think I’ll do that other thing where I throw a few pictures at you and catch you up on recent developments.

item.title: A New Thing?
item.description: I decided to do something today I’ve been wanting to do for quite a while. I’m bringing back what they used to call in the early days of podcasting “soundseeing tours”, wherein people just recorded the ambient sounds of interesting places they visited or things they were doing. Not much time to do a writeup on this, as I’m about to board my flight, but here you can join me on my customary walk from Tom Bradley International terminal across the length and breadth of the airport.

item.title: Gor
item.description: Earlier today I had the honor of being driven around by Gor, who I think is some sort of barbarian king in his main job.

item.title: More Pasadena Eats
Abiri Sushi and Ramen
item.description: Spicy tonkatsu ramen is why God created pigs, and the Japanese. üçúüç∂

item.title: Antiques, Part 3
Three New Pasadena Restaurants
item.description: I have decided that when presented with a choice between the familiar and the new, I am going to lean in favor of new experiences.

item.title: The diagonal crosswalks of Pasadena
item.description: One of the little things I appreciate about Old Town Pasadena are the diagonal crosswalks. Very convenient, but they always feel like I‚Äôm stepping out into traffic. üò≥üö∂üèª‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏èüöå

Today I had a lot of reminders that there are people out there who love and care for me a great deal. My wife, parents, and children. My brothers, cousins, and family. Friends old and new. I am thankful for all of them. I am thankful for the things I have, inside and out. I am thankful for the places God has brought me to in the past year.

item.title: Avocado Toast
item.description: It‚Äôs adorable the way these Californians go on about their avocado toast. I have heard ‚Äúavocado toast‚Äù dropped about five times in the last couple of days. Reminds me of the way Texans love… tacos? I think I‚Äôm gonna have to eat some avocado toast before I get out of here. I‚Äôll let you guys know. ü•ë

item.title: Pasadena in Bloom
item.description: The streets of Old Town Pasadena are lined this April in pink and purple blooms. A little natural spring beauty. Something of a birthday treat from God.

item.title: Roof Access
item.description: I get irrationally excited when I see ROOF ACCESS. But it‚Äôs never actually accessible.

item.title: Selfie from Cali
item.description: That‚Äôs a wrap for this trip. It‚Äôs been fun trying a new hotel and exploring a different part of the city. Perhaps next time I‚Äôll try to take in more of the cultural life. There‚Äôs always something going on in Pasadena. Now home again to Texas and the people I love. See you soon!

item.title: Pasadena Streets
A Half-Price Books?
Taco Libre
item.description:
The weather was warmer today. I could feel spring in my bones. I get that way around this time of year. Maybe I was feeling a little homesick. Whatever the case, I’ve been craving Mexican food. I noticed this little while walking around during my lunch break.

As I was standing outside the door reading the posted menuboard, an older lady passing by said to me “Go in. You’ll like it. It’s really good.” I took that as a sign.

item.title: Good Times at the El Portal
item.description: I took a detour that night after my trip to the antique store. I passed along back streets, out of the way plazas, anywhere that looked like it might afford me new scenery. I stumbled across El Portal behind the headquarters of the Planetary Society, its aromas drawing my attention before I’d even rounded the corner to lay site on the place.

item.title: Pasadena Street Musician
Horn Player
item.description: A street musician doing his thing in Old Town Pasadena.

item.title: Antiques, Part 2
Antiques
Pok√©mon Go In Pasadena
Old Methodist Church
item.description: The interesting things you run across when you decide to walk the mile and a half back to the hotel instead of Uber-ing. This is an old Methodist Church in the Playhouse District of Pasadena. Almost looks like an entrance to another world. A secret garden. A little foreboding perhaps. There was a lot about this area I‚Äôd like to explore. I‚Äôll be back again.

item.title: Let‚Äôs Play Poison
item.description: There’s someone buried under there. That’s the name. And see the date? Poison! Get off!

item.title: For the Lightly Bosomed Woman
item.description: I see what you did there, Flattery. And for the moderately bosomed woman? Out of luck, I suppose‚Ä¶ üëô

item.title: Back in L.A.
Scenes from the Lax International Terminal
Out West Again
item.description: What should I say? What can I say? Perhaps a little about where I find myself these days. What I’m up to. Best keep it brief. I want to encourage myself to update these pages a little more frequently this year.

item.title: Pasadena Eats
The Retro Store in Pasadena, California
Maneki Neko Exhibit at the San Francisco Airport
So Sick
item.description: Being sick on a trip is the worst. I’ve mostly been sleeping every spare moment I get. Managed to catch a pretty decent cheese ball of a movie, though. It was old school campy fun in the best way. Nicely captured the feel of old 80s schlock-horror movies like The Gate and Return of the Living Dead.

item.title: Greetings from Redwood City
